matched.actualTitle: Remote Code Execution via Command Injection in check_service Endpoint
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same command injection vulnerability in the check_service endpoint. The expected finding describes command injection via subprocess.check_output with shell=True and unsanitized service_name parameter. The actual finding provides detailed proof-of-concept showing the exact same vulnerability with validation bypass using '-t custom' prefix. The actual finding demonstrates successful RCE exploitation with commands like whoami, id, ls, and pwd, confirming the technical vulnerability described in the expected finding.

extra.title: Business Logic Flaw: All Services Report True Status Regardless of Actual State
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a valid business logic vulnerability where the /check_service endpoint returns status=true for all inputs regardless of whether services exist. This is a distinct vulnerability from the command injection and represents a separate design flaw in the service status checking logic.

extra.title: HTTP Parameter Pollution - Duplicate Parameter Handling
extra.assessment: New discovery - This vulnerability demonstrates that the application uses the last parameter value when duplicate service_name parameters are provided, enabling potential HPP attacks. This is a distinct input handling vulnerability separate from command injection.

extra.title: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) with ERB Templates
extra.assessment: New discovery - The endpoint crashes with HTTP 500 when ERB template syntax is provided, indicating the backend attempts template processing. This is a separate vulnerability from command injection, though potentially related to the eval() usage mentioned.

extra.title: Null Byte Injection Causing 500 Error / Application Crash
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application crashes when null bytes are included in the service_name parameter. This demonstrates improper input validation for control characters and is a separate vulnerability from command injection.

extra.title: Missing Authentication Controls on check_service Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /check_service endpoint has no authentication or authorization checks, allowing unauthenticated access. While not directly the command injection vulnerability, this enables exploitation of the RCE vulnerability without credentials, making the attack surface significantly larger.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing critical security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, HSTS, etc.) and exposes server version information. This is a separate security misconfiguration vulnerability.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Backend Shell Script Details Exposed
extra.assessment: New discovery - Error messages expose sensitive implementation details including backend script name (check_service.sh), command-line options, and usage examples. This information disclosure vulnerability helps attackers understand the backend and craft targeted exploits.

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - The endpoint lacks CSRF token validation, Origin/Referer validation, and SameSite cookie protection. While the current endpoint is read-only, this represents a systemic security weakness in request validation.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting on check_service Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - The endpoint has no rate limiting mechanism, allowing unlimited requests per IP/user. This enables DoS attacks and allows rapid exploitation of the RCE vulnerability without detection.

extra.title: Information Disclosure via Error Handling When HTML Tags Provided
extra.assessment: New discovery - HTML/XML tags bypass input validation but trigger HTTP 500 errors, indicating backend parsing logic failures. This represents a separate input handling vulnerability.

extra.title: Improper Input Type Validation Leading to Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - Non-string type values (null, integer, boolean) cause HTTP 500 errors instead of graceful rejection. This indicates missing type validation in the input handling.

extra.title: Type Confusion Vulnerability Causing Application Crash
extra.assessment: New discovery - The endpoint crashes when non-string types are passed for service_name parameter, showing inconsistent type handling that can be used for DoS attacks.

extra.title: Sensitive Information Exposure via Environment Variable Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - The RCE vulnerability allows attackers to execute the 'env' command and extract sensitive API keys (Anthropic API key, OpenRouter API key) and system configuration details. This is a critical information disclosure vulnerability enabled by the RCE vulnerability.
